issues.description: Parameter order for addParent is inconsistent between the problem statement/template and the solution. The problem description and the template declare addParent(Person person, Person parent) (child first, parent second), but the solution implements addParent(Person parent, Person person) (parent first, child second). Because both parameters have the same type (Person) this does not cause a compile error, but it inverts the semantic meaning of the arguments and is likely to confuse students when comparing template, specification and solution (and when reasoning about which object is modified and persisted).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the parameter order consistent across all artifacts. The simplest fix is to change the solution method signature to match the problem statement/template: public Person addParent(Person person, Person parent) { ... } and update the method body variable names accordingly (add parent to person's parents and save person). Alternatively, if the intended API is parent-first, update the problem statement and template to use that order — but ensure all three artifacts use the same parameter order and names to avoid semantic confusion.

issues.description: The problem statement and the template define the method signature addParent(Person person, Person parent) (child first, parent second). The solution implementation declares addParent(Person parent, Person person) — the parameter order is swapped. Meanwhile PersonResource (in both template and solution) calls personService.addParent(person, parent) (child then parent). This discrepancy between the expected API (problem + template + resource calls) and the solution's parameter ordering creates a mapping confusion: students expect to implement/use addParent(child, parent) as described, but the solution's service implementation uses the opposite parameter positions. This is an unintended identifier/parameter-order inconsistency that can mislead students about the intended API and method semantics.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the parameter ordering across all artifacts. Change the solution's PersonService.addParent signature to match the problem and template: public Person addParent(Person person, Person parent) { /* use person.getParents().add(parent); return personRepository.save(person); */ }. Alternatively, if the swapped order was intentional, update the problem statement, template stubs, and PersonResource calls to use addParent(Person parent, Person person) consistently — but the least disruptive fix is to update the solution to use (person, parent).
